title: At 10,000 and Counting, This Company Is Flooding the U.S. With Tariff Appeals
text:
Blaine, Minn.-based Arrowhead, which employs about 1,000 people, hired a crew of temp workers to submit requests for tariff relief manually.

WASHINGTON—U.S. companies have filed more than 16,000 requests for exemptions from the $200 billion tranche of tariffs on Chinese goods that the Trump administration imposed one year ago. Of those appeals, over 10,000 have come from just one company: Arrowhead Engineered Products Inc. of Blaine, Minn.

Arrowhead imports thousands of aftermarket repair parts for cars, lawn mowers, all-terrain vehicles and other items from China, which are now all being taxed with a 25% tariff that is set to jump to 30% on Oct. 15.

The duties have undermined Arrowhead’s business model of selling cheaper alternatives to manufacturers’ parts, company officials say. Appealing the levies has proved a challenge in itself, illustrating the trade war’s sometimes hidden toll on U.S. companies.

“We basically put everything else on the back burner” to appeal the tariffs, said John Mosunic, Arrowhead’s chief operating officer.

Seeing no viable alternatives to the many parts it imports from China, Arrowhead contacted the office of its local congressman, Rep. Tom Emmer (R., Minn.), to see if there was any way to streamline the appeals process.

The guidance Arrowhead received: Be as specific as you can in seeking exemptions, Mr. Mosunic said. So Arrowhead, which employs about 1,000 people, ended up filing appeals for each gasket, air filter, spark plug and other parts it imports, hiring a crew of temp workers to submit the requests manually.

An Arrowhead employee unpacks products shipped from China. The company was told to be as specific as possible in asking the government for tariff exemptions. Photo: Jenn Ackerman for The Wall Street Journal

Companies have taken different approaches to the exclusion process. Some have filed only for a few key items. Others have filed single applications that cover many products, especially if those items all fall under the same 10-digit code in the tariff schedule.

Trade attorneys and experts say it isn’t clear which tack is more effective.

“If I had figured out the secret recipe that explains approvals, I’d be speaking from the beach,” said Ted Murphy, a partner in the international trade practice at Sidley Austin LLP.

The Office of the U.S. Trade Representative has said it would evaluate appeals individually, weighing factors such as whether a product is only available from China and whether duties would harm the company significantly.

Trade experts say navigating the process is especially tough on smaller companies with limited resources.

“Small businesses wouldn’t have that kind of money to hire one of the well-connected firms,” said Clark Packard, the trade policy counsel at the free market think tank R Street Institute and a former Republican policy adviser. “For an administration that claims to be ‘draining the swamp,’ it’s certainly been a bonanza for trade lawyers and lobbyists.”

The Wall Street Journal analyzed filings posted on a website maintained by the USTR. Several hundred new filings have been added each day in recent weeks; the analysis covers filings posted through Friday.

President Trump has repeatedly said tariffs are being paid by China, but in fact they are shouldered by U.S. importers. In filing after filing, companies said the higher costs threatened their survival and that they had no alternatives to the Chinese products.

“It is not economically feasible for this irrigation-grade component to be manufactured in the U.S.,” XCAD USA, an Idaho-based maker of sprinklers and other irrigation components, said in its filing.

Becky Oja, the company’s controller and the lone employee filing requests, said she started building a spreadsheet in June to track information the government required, including confidential sales data. Employees helped her prep by weighing, measuring and describing how each component works.

“We only have 15 employees—we’re very small potatoes over here in Idaho,” Ms. Oja said. “Every little fitting and tube for the plumbing of [a product] has to be input into the exclusion request.”

American Scientific, which supplies science products for educational purposes, has submitted more than 100 requests for items including beakers and prisms of various sizes and two colors of litmus paper that it says it can’t find outside China.

The company said the tariffs could force schools to cut back. “The school-system budgets are remaining the same and will have to buy 25% less equipment in an environment where education materials are already scarce and [the] level of education is suffering,” the company said in a filing.

Lawyers and consultants that some companies have hired to manage the complexities of the process say their clients are overwhelmed.

“We’re taking clients through the stages of grief,” said Mr. Murphy of Sidley Austin LLP, which helps companies navigate the new trade rules. “They’re in denial; they’re angry. Eventually you get to acceptance that this is U.S. trade policy.”

Arrowhead’s warehouse contains thousands of gaskets, air filters, spark plugs and other parts. The company has filed for tariff relief on many such items one by one. Photo: Jenn Ackerman for The Wall Street Journal

When the tariff appeals process opened on June 30, a Sunday, John Hoge of Sea Eagle Boats Inc. came into the office early to begin seeking exemptions for the inflatable sea kayaks his company imports from China.

“These are not products that can lead to strategic dominance of the world,” Mr. Hoge said.

The small family business had already paid nearly $200,000 with a 10% tariff on its products, just as that duty was set to rise to 25%.

“The tariffs were an existential threat to our business,” said Mr. Hoge. “We’ve been in business for 62 years, but we’ve never experienced anything like this and it was vital to get ahead of it.”

As one of the first applicants, Sea Eagle has gotten decisions: Seven of its requests were granted; 11 were denied. Mr. Hoge says he doesn’t know why some were accepted and others weren’t.

The USTR, in its decision letter on the denied products, said “the request failed to show that the imposition of additional duties on the particular product would cause severe economic harm to you or other U.S. interests.”

On Friday, the USTR granted exemptions for more than 400 additional items, primarily applications that had been filed on earlier tranches of tariffs. The decisions included 10 product exclusions requested by Apple Inc. for items such as its Magic Mouse 2 and internal PC components.

About 540 companies have submitted just one request for exclusion from the $200 billion list, according to the Journal’s analysis. More than 93% of the companies have submitted 10 requests or fewer.

Arrowhead—under its former name, Arrowhead Electrical Products—filed 474 exclusion requests under the tariffs imposed on $34 billion of Chinese goods in July 2018. About 35% of those requests were granted, according to USTR data.

Its current requests for more than 10,000 exemptions are for items on a list of roughly $200 billion worth of Chinese goods that were first targeted with tariffs in September 2018, at a rate of 10%. Mr. Trump raised those levies to 25% in May, and they are set to go to 30% on Oct. 15.

To work as repair parts, Arrowhead’s imports are carefully specified, making it difficult for the firm to switch suppliers, though it has been looking wherever it can, Mr. Mosunic said.

“The whole idea with aftermarket parts is to find a lower-cost source,” said Mr. Mosunic. “And for a lot of these components there’s no U.S. source, period,” he said. “You can’t do it anymore—it’s gone. Alternators, starters haven’t been manufactured in the U.S. for 20 years.”

Write to Josh Zumbrun at Josh.Zumbrun@wsj.com
description: President Trump has said China is paying the cost of tariffs, but many U.S. importers see them as threats and are racing to seek exemptions. One such company has filed nearly two-thirds of all appeals.
